column1: More serious conditions that can lead to light-headedness include: - Heart problems, such as a heart attack or abnormal heart beat - Stroke - Bleeding inside the body - Shock (extreme drop in blood pressure) If any of these serious disorders are present, you will usually also have symptoms like chest pain, a feeling of a racing heart, loss of speech, change in vision, or other symptoms.

Vertigo may be due to: - Benign positional vertigo, a spinning feeling that occurs when you move your head - Labyrinthitis, a viral infection of the inner ear that usually follows a cold or flu - Meniere's disease, a common inner ear problem Other causes of lightheadedness or vertigo may include: - Use of certain medicines - Stroke - Multiple sclerosis - Seizures - Brain tumor - Bleeding in the brain
If you have vertigo, the following tips can help prevent your symptoms from becoming worse: - Keep still and rest when symptoms occur.
